page.title: 11Henry Cooke Beetham
page.content: There was a mill on this site in the fourteenth centuary. It was used for various purposes. It was a corn mill,a pulling mill for wool and in the fifteenth centuary it became a paper mill. In 1788 it became Thomas Cookes. The name was transfered from Yorkshire by Thomas Lumb.He was such a hard man that he was said to have been quarried not born. It made hand made paper out of cotton and rags. It now makes specialised paper from wood pulp imported from Europe. It employs about two hundred and fifty people some work shift hours to keep the mill running round the clock.It shuts down on Sunday for maintance.Their future is optimistic.They have recenttly invested heavily.
